The Schelling Coin protocol is a method for achieving consensus on a single value among decentralized participants. It works by having participants submit a secret number (the "commitment"), and then revealing their numbers. The protocol then selects the value that was closest to the median of all revealed numbers as the consensus value.

Here is a summary of the protocol in simple steps:

1. Participants submit a secret number (the "commitment")
2. Participants reveal their secret numbers
3. The median of all revealed numbers is calculated
4. The value closest to the median is chosen as the consensus value

The protocol can also be used for other types of decision-making, such as choosing a leader or determining the outcome of a vote.

Here is a table that illustrates the process:

| Commitment | Revealed Number |
| --- | --- |
| 5 | 5 |
| 6 | 6 |
| 7 | 7 |
| 8 | 8 |
| 9 | 9 |

Median = 7

The closest number to the median is 7, so 7 is chosen as the consensus value.
